reviewText: This is a great old (1956) classic movie with a younger Burt Lancaster and a very young looking Tony Curtis. The Very 1950's romantic interest is provided by Gina Lollobrigida, an Italian Marilyn Monroe, without Marilyn's humor. I must say she does as good an acting job as possible with a poorly written, and thankless sex object role. The best part of this movie though is the trapeze itself. This is Burt Lancaster at his best. The circus environment and background is wonderfully realized. Tony Curtis is also close to his best. I doubt very much there will ever be a remake of this one and even if there is one, it will have a hard time beating this classic.

reviewText: Hurry, hurry, hurry! Step right up, folks! See Burton Stephen Lancaster perform actual death-defying stunts high overhead, just as he did in his youthful circus days! See Bernard Schwartz (you know him as Tony Curtis) actually walk on his hands! That's right folks, ya gotta see it to believe it! And if that ain't enough for ya, we have Luigina Lollobrigida in her American film debut! The lovely 28-year-old will absolutely take your breath away as Lola, the hypotenuse of this high-flying love triangle that's set right under our big top. There's also lots of real circus performers in this "guaranteed thrill-a-minute adventure" folks, so... hurry, hurry, hurry!!!Hey, Rube! Cecil B. DeMille'sTHE GREATEST SHOW ON EARTHis a not-to-be-missed three ring extravaganza!Parenthetical number prior to title is a 1 to 10 viewer poll rating found at a film research website.(6.6) Trapeze (1956) - Burt Lancaster/Tony Curtis/Gina Lollobrigida/Katy Jurado/Thomas Gomez/Johnny Puleo/Minor WatsonCAST TRIVIA--Burt Lancaster's acrobatic career ended with an injury that wasn't severe enough to keep him out of the military during WWII.Tony Curtis appears as part of the group collage on the cover of the Beatles album, Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band.Mexican-born Katy Jurado's ex-husband, Ernest Borgnine, called her, "beautiful, but a tiger."Little person Johnny Puleo (Max) was a harmonica playing recording artist with his group, The Harmonica Gang.

reviewText: This review refers to the recent MGM "made to order" DVD release. This DVD is a "bare-bones" copy of this 1956 action/drama, with no "extras" - you put it the player and it plays the movie, just like a VHS tape.It is a high-quality copy in anamorphic widescreen video, and NTSC (US standard) video format. The picture is sharp, and colors are very good throughout.The story line between two men and a woman (Burt Lancaster, Tony Curtis, Gina Lollobrigida) is fairly predictable but well-done, and the action sequences are magnificent (Lancaster, once a circus performer, doing his own trapeze work - including the triple).Trapeze
summary: Excellent DVD Copy of 1950s Action Film

reviewText: From reading other reviews I gather that there is a lot of confusion about this DVD release of TRAPEZE, a most excellent film.For some reason, the back of the case says that this DVD is "full screen" (i.e. panned and scanned to fit on a 4:3 aspect ratio TV screen.)  Amazon's description says it's in a 2.35:1 aspect ratio, the standard for CinemaScope, which is letterboxed (i.e. has black bars at top and bottom) even on a 16:9 aspect ratio TV.  Amazon is right.  If you want to see the picture as it originally played in theaters this is the DVD you want.It has been mentioned by some reviewers that the picture quality is not the best.  While this DVD is not from a restored print, the picture quality is quite good.  At the risk of revealing my age, I'll admit that I saw it in a theater when it was new and this print looks very good to me even on a 42 inch widescreen LCD TV.The film was produced by Joanna Productions, part of Hecht-Hill-Lancaster, which was one of the most prominent Hollywood independent production companies of the 1950's and 60's.  Most of the films they produced are now considered great classics and the rest are considered quite good.  It was released by United Artists, a name that was associated with quality films from the day of its founding in 1919 until the great HEAVEN'S GATE fiasco of 1980.It's important to note that most film production companies have not retained the rights to their own libraries, frequently selling them to other companies.  From the late 1970's up to the present day the film production world has been engaged in a frantic series of mergers, de-mergers and buy-outs that have created something akin to corporate incest.  Thus the film libraries have changed hands (sometimes along with the companies and sometimes separately) so many times that it's almost impossible for someone not closely involved to know who owns what.  As close as I can figure, United Artists sold its library to MGM which, in turn, sold it to 20th Century Fox.  It appears that Fox now owns the distribution rights to TRAPEZE.  While MGM's logo appears on the front of the DVD case, both the MGM and Fox logos appear on the back and the fine print says that the DVD is distributed under license from Fox.Since Fox had nothing to do with the original production of TRAPEZE, it's highly unlikely that they are going to produce a proper restoration of the film or a DVD release with things like commentary or special features any time soon.  They have their own library to work on.  So be thankful that we have this DVD and enjoy it.  It's a great film!

reviewText: If you haven't seen the film, I guarantee you this is the finest film you've never seen.  The great character actor Burt Lancaster was the star; it was a film made for him insofar as he had the talent, and guts, to actually do some of the scenes on the trapeze.The film is a love triangle, including Tony Curtis and Gina Lollobrigida, set within the confines of a tiny circus, permanently playing in a Paris neighborhood.  The rivalry is perfectly developed and run parallel to the development of a trapeze relationship and partnership of Lancaster and Curtis.  The (trapeze) action is great, the love triangle interfering but only when it must.  Overall, a great film.
summary: One of the best films you've never seen

reviewText: This was available as a MGM widescreen laserdisc, and was worth a decent amount before this DVD was released. I can tell you, having owned both, that this film looks much better now that its super-widescreen format has been enhanced for 16:9. It is very enjoyable to watch and I did not find the video transfer obstructed the story or technical aspects of the production. No, it has not been remastered and there is not a whole lot of "pop" to the image -- but in some ways, I enjoy older transfers because there is no threat of DNR or obnoxious boosting of color saturation.The film itself is a well directed story of rivalry and melodrama beneath the big top. It's got a decent plot about battling Trapeze artists, but the CinemaScope photography is truly spectacular. This is a real gem from the 1950s, directed by Carol Reed, and filmed in the neighborhoods of Paris by Robert Krasker, the cinematographer who shot "El Cid" and "The Third Man".The reason I just cannot enjoy the film more is because of Burt Lancaster. I'm not a fan of his over and underacting approach to characters; it seems like he's always furious or getting soft & mushy. Tony Curtis is pretty mild-mannered here so he's fine, and I prefer him to Lancaster in both this film and "Sweet Smell of Success". Now, this is a very subjective criticism but you're going to se a lot of fuming Lancaster in "Trapeze". Still, a great, underappreciated film about the old circus environment, and a must-see for anyone who loves CinemaScope.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'd like to preface this review by paying tribute to Tony Curtis.  Not given a lot of respect in his lifetime, Curtis was usually given grudging praise when he delivered a good performance.  Truth be told Curtis was usually good, sometimes great, more often than not.  All one has to do is reference "The Sweet Smell of Success", "The Defiant Ones", and "Some Like It Hot" to make the case.  As for this film, well, it's backstage melodrama albeit superb backstage melodrama.  This isn't deep think but a great popcorn movie.  It's graced by terrific production values and cinematography which shouldn't come as any surprise for a film directed by Carol Reed ("The Third Man").  You can almost smell the sweat and straw from the film's circus setting.  The highwire scenes are equally thrilling.  Burt Lancaster and Curtis give good accounts as acrobats and Gina Lollobrigida is...eye candy.  Five star eye candy, though.  Special note should be made for Katy Jurado as a former flame of Lancaster's.  Jurado was a great actress of her day and probably doesn't get the recognition she deserves.  Curtis made better films than "Trapeze" but you can't go wrong by viewing this in homage to a true Hollywood legend.

reviewText: The primary actors were all 3 at the top of their game and popularity at the time this movie was made.  Burt Lancaster's background as a circus aerialist made him the perfect choice for his part and Tony Curtis was young and athletic enough to perform some of the  act to look credible.  They both played well off the most beautiful actress of the era, Gina Lollogrigida, who proved that she was more than gorgeous but could also act...because of her looks I think many critics dismissed her acting but I think she did a terrific job as the scheming woman looking to get ahead at any cost.The actual aerial work is stunning regardless of who was really doing the "doubles" and "triples"...highly recommended

reviewText: "Trapeze" (1956) is one of the best circus films with marvelous performances from Burt Lancaster, Tony Curtis, and Gina Lollobrigida. Other notable circus films include Tod Browning's "Freaks" (1932) and "The Unknown" (1927), "The Marx Brothers at the Circus" (1938), "Dumbo" (1941), "The Greatest Show on Earth" (1952), "La Strada" (1956), and "The Great Wallendas" (1978)Burt Lancaster (1913-94) plays a world class trapeze artist working as a rigger as a result of a failed "triple" summersault. Lancaster was noted for his athleticism ("Flame and the Arrow", "Jim Thorpe", "Crimson Pirate"), his intensity ("Come Back Little Sheba", "From Here to Eternity", "The Rose Tattoo", "Elmer Gantry"), and his marvelous westerns ("Gunfight at OK Corral", "Vera Cruz", "The Professionals" , "Valdez is Coming"), but it's his character studies in this film, "Birdman of Alcatraz" (1962), and "Atlantic City" (1980) where we really see his true power as an actor.Lancaster was nominated for an Oscar for "From Here to Eternity" (1953) and would be nominated 3 more times and win for "Elmer Gantry" (1960). He was nominated for a Golden Globe 5 times, starting in 1956 ("The Rainmaker") and including "Birdman of Alcatraz" (1962) and "Atlantic City" (1980). He appears as #19 on the AFI list of Top 50 Screen Legends.FWIW - Lancaster does all his own stunts.Boyishly handsome Tony Curtis (`1925-2010) plays the young flyer who wants Lancaster to teach him the "triple". Curtis was probably one of the most under-rated actors of his era.  For "The Defiant Ones" (1958) he was nominated for an Oscar, a BAFTA, and a Golden Globe, yet his excellent performances in hits like "Some Like it Hot" (1959) "Spartacus" (1960) and "The Boston Strangler" (1968) went unrecognized. Curtis had three problems - his deadly good looks, his divorce from Janet Leigh, and his Brooklyn accent.FWIW - Lancaster was one of the first people to take an interest in Curtis and got him signed with his own agent.This was the second US film for beautiful and shapely Gina Lollobrigida (1927) who had been making films in Europe since 1946. In 1961 she won a Golden Globe as World's Favorite Actress. Lollobrigida plays a woman who will do whatever she has to in order to achieve fame in the circus world, even if it means breaking up Lancaster and Curtis.Excellent support comes from Thomas Gomez (1905-71) as the circus owner and Katy Gurado (1924-2002) as a former lover of Lancaster. Larger than life Gomez was nominated for an Oscar for "Ride the Pink Horse" (1947). He could play the hero (Abe Saperstein in "The Harlem Globetrotters") and the villain (Curly in "Key Largo") with equal skill.Jurado won the Golden Globe for her role in "High Noon" (1952) and was nominated for an Oscar for "Broken Lance" (1954), but I think her very best performance was as Chill Wills' wife in "Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid" (1972).Director Carol Reed (1906-76) was nominated 3 times for an Oscar and won for "Oliver" (1968) and won Palme d'Or for "The Third Man" (1949). He made 33 films between 1935 and 1972.The project was produced by Hecht-Hill-Lancaster, which involved producer Harold Hecht (1907-85), writer James Hill (1916-2001) and Lancaster. They made two dozen films, many of which Lancaster appeared in ("Ulzana's Raid", "Birdman of Alcatraz", "Devil's Disciple", "Run Silent, Run Deep", "Sweet Smell of Success").In 1956 viewers were lured by the blockbusters - "The Ten Commandments", "Around the World in 80 days", "War and Peace", and "The King and I" were the box office favorites. The Oscars went to "Giant" (Director), "Anastasia" (Actress), and "Lust for Life" (Supporting Actor). Other notable films that year included "The Searchers", "Baby Doll", "The Rainmaker", and "Bus Stop".This is a great film, not only for the behind the scenes look at circus life but also for the great character studies involving the three central characters.

reviewText: A good old fasioned circus movie with excellent acting by the cast. Burt Lancaster is great as usual. Tony Curtis is excellent nevertheless and nothwithstanding his unmistakable Bronx accent. Gina Lolbridgida effective as the woman who will do anything to put herself in the spotlight as a trapeze artist.  Very fine drama and excellent touches make this an exceptionally enjoyable movie. Good production values and the fact that Lancaster did all his own stunts make it more worth watching. The twist at the end was a big surprise to me, as I'm sure it will be to other viewers.  A winner in all ways. Never stops moving and most engrossing from start to finish. A tribute to the three top stars and good supporting cast, as well. I liked this movie very much and remembered it from when I first saw it as a child years ago at the Freeman Theater in The Bronx. If you like good circus movies, and so few of them are good, I recommend this movie as it has good acting, good acts, and will hold your attention due to the back scene drama that unfolds. Full marks for all involved!
summary: Fast moving, good drama and action in the circus!

reviewText: I was in Paris early this week and decided to have a look at the Cirque d'Hiver, where TRAPEZE was shot, over 55 years ago.  I was very moved, as I walked around, trying to figure out where Burt Lancaster, Tony Curtis, Gina Lollobrigida and Katy Jurado had performed their scenes, the metro entrance from where Tony Curtis comes out in the very beginning of the film, the local cafés that may have been used for specific scenes.  Everything is there, still, even if most of the performers are long gone now.  I love TRAPEZE.  I saw it when I was ten years old and must have watched it over 20 times ever since.  I love the story, I love the atmospheric Paris locations, I love the actors, the cinematography, the music, everything.  Carol Reed must be remembered as a great director and TRAPEZE is undoubtedby one of his best films. I have never seen a better film about the circus world, for sure.  You have a clear sense of the actors' total commitment to the film, you feel they gave their best in every scene you see before you.  I do think TRAPEZE is just about perfect.  It may not be considered a masterpiece by highbrow critics but it is perfect, all the same. I will always remember Lollobrigida doing her rope act to seduce Lancaster and I will always remember the pain experienced by the triangle of lovers as the film reaches its climax. Thank you, Burt, Tony, Gina, Katy.  How wonderful you were!
summary: The best film about the circus world, ever!

reviewText: Why all the whining? I got this in hopes it was the same movie from TV many decades ago. NO the color is not as awesome as it is in today's movies. Back then they used film, not computers. NO the sound is not as awesome as George Lucas can make it. This was made before they launched Sputnik for heaven's sake! Cut them some slack! Back then they did things differently. But know what? This film was made on location in Paris, at a circus no less! Not a sound stage in Burbank. Because of that the film has an ambiance and feeling that captures you from the very start.  The color looks absolutely fine on my 50" LCD screen and the sound is fine. It's not a widescreen movie but my TV has settings to stretch it and it still looks fine. If you are an audiophile who loves 7.1 surround-sound then don't buy the movie.I am not at all disappointed! The reviews here had me worried so I had to speak out! It's a good movie and I am happy with it!Now, the box has English and Chinese writing on it so I was worried.  Will this be dubbed with horrible results? No, the subtitles are hidden unless you want them. And the disc is Region 0 so you can play it anywhere in the world. The entire movie is in English with no issues at all.So in conclusion, if you are wondering if this movie is the one to get, yes it is. You will enjoy it for what it is. So there. :-)
summary: Great movie, as to be expected!

reviewText: Burt Lancaster traded on his former life as a trapeze artist for this melodrama, easily one of the most enjoyable of circus movies. He plays a famed flyer who is coaxed back after an accident that has left him with a limp by Tony Curtis, who wants to learn the near impossible triple somersault, until Gina Lollabrigida muscles in on their act and sets them against each other. Lancaster is on great form, either in the air or pinching his unwanted protégée's drink, Curtis (doubled in the acrobatic scenes by Lancaster's former circus partner Nick Cravat) is amiably enthusiastic, and La Lollabrigida is about as subtle as a flying sledgehammer, delivering lines like "I wuz alwayz strong in da legs" for considerably more than they're worth.With a colourful supporting cast, including snake-hater Sid James trying to sell a used python (he apparently took the part to pay off another gambling debt), and a terrific array of behind-the-scenes talent (director Carol Reed, cinematographer Robert Krasker, composer Malcolm Arnold), Trapeze is a lavishly produced audience picture with a few inspired moments in the air. The first performance is a terrific piece of direction and editing and looks terrific in widescreen. This is a film that makes such full use of the Scope ratio that it's always been marred by panning-and-scanning on TV, very consciously designed for the CinemaScope screen that at the time was almost as big a draw as the stars at the box-office, so it's good to see the original ratio preserved on this PAL DVD even if the print is a tad grainy in places.
